claim.text: Meta Agent Search discovers agents that substantially outperform state-of-the-art hand-designed baselines across multiple domains
claim.exact_quote: Our experiments show that the discovered agents substantially outperform state-of-the-art hand-designed baselines.

evidence.evidence_text: Results across multiple domains show Meta Agent Search discovered agents outperforming baselines with significant margins
evidence.exact_quote: The results across multiple domains demonstrate that Meta Agent Search can discover agents that outperform state-of-the-art hand-designed agents (Table 1)

conclusion.limitations: While results are strong, they are limited to specific benchmark tasks rather than real-world applications

claim.text: The discovered agents maintain superior performance when transferred across domains and models
claim.exact_quote: Importantly, we consistently observe the surprising result that agents invented by Meta Agent Search maintain superior performance even when transferred across domains and models, demonstrating their robustness and generality.

evidence.evidence_text: Transfer performance across models on ARC challenge
evidence.exact_quote: As shown in Table 3, we observe that the searched agents consistently outperform the hand-designed agents with a substantial gap

evidence.evidence_text: Transfer performance across math and non-math domains
evidence.limitations: Performance not fully matching domain-specific agents
evidence.exact_quote: While the performance of agents originally searched in the math domain does not fully match that of agents specifically designed for the target domains, they still outperform (in Reading Comprehension and Multi-task) or match (in Science) the state-of-the-art hand-designed agent baselines

conclusion.limitations: Transfer performance varies across domains, with stronger results within similar domains

claim.text: The paper describes a newly forming research area called Automated Design of Agentic Systems (ADAS)
claim.exact_quote: We describe a newly forming research area, Automated Design of Agentic Systems (ADAS), which aims to automatically create powerful agentic system designs, including inventing novel building blocks and/or combining them in new ways.

conclusion.limitations: No direct evidence provided in the excerpt for describing this as a research area

claim.text: Agents improve F1 scores on reading comprehension tasks by 13.6/100 and accuracy rates on math tasks by 14.4%
claim.exact_quote: For instance, our agents improve F1 scores on reading comprehension tasks by 13.6/100 and accuracy rates on math tasks by 14.4%.

evidence.evidence_text: Specific improvement metrics in reading comprehension and math
evidence.exact_quote: We want to highlight the substantial gap between the learned agents and hand-designed agents in the Reading Comprehension and Math domains, with improvements in F1 scores by 13.6/100 and accuracy rates by 14.4%, respectively

conclusion.limitations: Specific to particular datasets and model configurations

claim.text: Discovered agents improve accuracy over baselines by 25.9% and 13.2% on GSM8K and GSM-Hard math tasks when transferring across domains
claim.exact_quote: Additionally, they improve accuracy over baselines by 25.9% and 13.2% on GSM8K and GSM-Hard math tasks, respectively, after transferring across domains.

evidence.evidence_text: Transfer performance on GSM8K and GSM-Hard
evidence.exact_quote: Notably, our agents improve accuracy by 25.9% on GSM8K and 13.2% on GSM-Hard compared to the baselines when transferring within math domains

conclusion.limitations: Results specific to math domain transfer, may not generalize to other types of transfers

claim.text: There is an unexplored yet promising approach to ADAS where agents can be defined in code and new agents can be discovered automatically by a meta agent
claim.exact_quote: We further demonstrate that there is an unexplored yet promising approach within ADAS where agents can be defined in code and new agents can be automatically discovered by a meta agent programming ever better ones in code.

conclusion.limitations: No direct evidence provided demonstrating this is unexplored or demonstrating promise

claim.text: Programming languages as search space theoretically enables discovering any possible agentic system
claim.exact_quote: Given that programming languages are Turing Complete, this approach theoretically enables the learning of any possible agentic system: including novel prompts, tool use, workflows, and combinations thereof.

conclusion.limitations: Theoretical claim without supporting evidence or proof

claim.text: Meta Agent Search demonstrates progressive discovery of agents that outperform state-of-the-art hand-designed baselines and invent novel design patterns
claim.exact_quote: Overall, the results showcase the potential of ADAS and the effectiveness of Meta Agent Search to progressively discover agents that outperform state-of-the-art hand-designed baselines and invent novel design patterns through the innovation and combination of various stepping stones.

evidence.evidence_text: Progressive discovery demonstrated in ARC challenge
evidence.exact_quote: As shown in Figure 3a, Meta Agent Search effectively and progressively discovers agents that perform better than state-of-the-art hand-designed baselines

Careful observation of the search progress reveals that this sophisticated feedback mechanism did not appear suddenly. Instead, the ideas of incorporating diverse feedback, evaluating for various specific traits (via experts) such as efficiency and simplicity, and simulating human-like feedback emerged in iterations 5, 11, and 12, respectively

conclusion.limitations: Evolution of design patterns shown only for ARC challenge case study
